newsitem.title: UK: ICI shares hit two-year lows on downgrades.
newsitem.headline: ICI shares hit two-year lows on downgrades.

text.p: Shares in British chemical giant Imperial Chemical Industries Plc touched a two-year low on Monday as analysts dropped earnings estimates amid talk of continuing pricing pressures on the group.
ICI shares ended the day were down 14 pence at 688-1/2 in volume of 4.4 million shares, after earlier touching a low of 680p -- the lowest since March 1995.
Dealers said the latest round of downgrades followed briefings with the company on trading in the first quarter.
HSBC James Capel analyst David Ingles said a hoped-for improvement in trading conditions during the first quarter of the year had not materialised.
Instead, pricing pressures continued in a range of basic materials such as PTA and PET -- used in making plastics -- and titanium dioxide, used to give whiteness to paint and paper products.

"Everyone knows they had a pretty awful start to the year and it's not going to get better overnight," said Ingles. "I do think prices are beginning to make progress but it's just not being shown yet in ICI's results."
A spokesman for ICI declined comment on the latest downgrades.

He said any briefings for analysts would have been part of normal contacts with the company before the start of its "closed" season, when official comment is effectively barred in the run-up to results. ICI reports first quarter results on April 24.
Capel's Ingles lowered his 1997 pre-tax, pre-exceptional profit estimate to 600 million pounds from 750 million and cut his 1998 forecast to 800 million pounds from 900 million.
Ingles, who repeated a "sell" rating on ICI shares, also expects ICI to take a 100 million restructuring charge in both years.

At SBC Warburg analysts cut their current-year estimate to 565 million pounds from 635 million while rating the stock a "buy," and at NatWest analysts said their forecasts "look vulnerable" and repeated a "hold" rating.
ICI shares have underperformed the All-Share index by 22 percent in the last six months and 34 percent over the past 12 month period.

However, Ingles said the disappointing performance by ICI should not necessarily reflect on the rest of the chemical sector. "A lot of the second line chemical shares are looking very good value," he said.
ICI continues to be hit by its exposure to a weak plastics market, where profits and sales last year were affected by a combination of weak demand and overcapacity.
In PET, where prices fell around 30 percent in 1996, overcapacity is expected to continue to keep prices weak this year. ICI has a share of around eight percent of the world PET market.
Earnings last year were also hit by sudden downturns in prices of titanium dioxide and intermediate chemicals.
Analysts said sterling's strength is also weighing on the company, both in translational terms and in terms of the group's competitive position.
Although most of the UK chemicals industry is expected to benefit from a more benign outlook on feedstock prices this year, ICI is a feedstock manufacturer as well as end user.

The group has a declared aim of revamping its portfolio to move into higher margin, less cyclical businesses, building up its position in areas like polyurethanes, acrylics, performance chemicals and paints.
However, analysts said such businesses are in demand and come with a high price tag.
